item.title: Something for the Weekend – 01/02/25
item.content:encoded:
https://www.thesixthaxis.com/2025/02/01/something-for-the-weekend-01-02-25/

You know you’ve been watching too much NFL when the Six Nations kicks off and you get mildly confused by the try and conversion scores, and think that the yellow cards look soft – though there’s very good reasons for being that strict!

Pour one out for any Welsh friends and relatives you have after last night’s opener, but today should provide some fun for the Scottish and Irish out there.

But on to the video games news of the week.

In the News This Week

It’s quite a news-ful week, it feels like. There’s some systemic changes for both PlayStation and Xbox fans, there was some sad game studio news, and some re-releases for classic games.

  • Forza Horizon 5 is coming to PS5 this spring
  • The Sims 1 & 2 have been re-released for the series’ 25th birthday
  • BioWare is “downsizing” as next Mass Effect remains in pre-production
  • Phoenix Lab lays off “majority of the studio” leaving Dauntless and Fae Farm future in doubt
  • Sony makes PSN optional on PC games with new incentives for signing in
  • Indiana Jones hits 4 million players, but Xbox revenue and hardware sales fall
  • Is This Seat Taken? is a polite and cosy puzzler where you have to consider other people’s feelings
  • MultiVersus will shut down and go offline only after Season 5
  • Killing Floor 3 launches on 25th March 25 with Closed Beta in February
  • Dino Crisis is back with enhanced PC releases on GOG.com
  • PS Plus monthly games won’t guarantee PS4 games from January 2026
  • The PS Plus Monthly Games for February 2025 gets heisting with Payday 3

Games in Review & Featured Articles

It was reviews around the clock this week, but what stood out?

  • Bloomtown: A Different Story – PS5, XSX|S, PS4, XBO, NSW, PC – 9/10
  • Eternal Strands – PS5, XSX|S, PC – 8/10
  • The Mute House – PC – 7/10
  • Sniper Elite: Resistance – PS5, XSX|S, PS4, XBO, PC – 7/10
  • Orcs Must Die! Deathtrap – XSX|S, PC – 7/10
  • Tails of Iron 2: Whiskers of Winter – PS5, XSX|S, PS4, XBO, NSW, PC – 7/10
  • Laika: Aged Through Blood – Switch Review – 7/10
  • Cuisineer – PS5, XSX|S, NSW, PC – 5/10
  • Neptunia Riders VS Dogoos – PS5, PS4, PC – 4/10

Elsewhere, Tuffcub asked why Sony has spent so much money of their failed Games As Service push, while overlooking what could have been an easy win?

I’ve also been driving things, first with a look at the imperfect Assetto Corsa EVO Early Access release, and then keeping to the tracks of Tramau’s streets in City Transport Simulator: Tram.

Rounding out the week, What We Played featured Eternal Strands, Cuisineer and the Retroid Pocket 5.

Trailer Park

RoadCraft’s MudRunner disaster spin-off is coming out in May

Gran Turismo 7 update 1.55 adds 90s inspired Formula car

Split Fiction’s new trailer showcases its fantastical co-op action and some spectacular side content

That’s the round up for this week. Hope you have a great weekend ahead!

item.title: Spider-Man 2 PC port gets a rough reception over performance and graphical issues
item.content:encoded:
https://www.thesixthaxis.com/2025/02/01/spider-man-2-pc-port-gets-a-rough-reception-over-performance-and-graphical-issues/

The PC port of Marvel’s Spider-Man 2 launched on Thursday, but the game has had a “Mixed” reception in the Steam user reviews as many players complain about performance, graphical issues and crashes.

Sony leant on their in-house porting team at Nixxes to handle the port of Spider-Man 2, but while they traditionally have a good reputation for their PC ports, this one has fallen flat, joining a number of other PlayStation PC ports that have had a rocky landing.

We’re working on our own impressions of the PC port, but just to grab one of the many negative Steam reviews, “I have an RTX 4070ti, on high graphics and no raytracing I get crashes […] Even when it’s not crashing, shadows flicker for no good reason and it feels like it struggles to render hair at times.”

Part of this is down to performance. While Spider-Man Remastered and Miles Morales were well received for their performance, those games fundamentally had the PS4 platform as the base target for Insomniac’s original creation, and were designed with ray tracing as an additive feature. Spider-Man 2 only launched for PS5 and so could always feature ray tracing, could always rely on the fast NVMe SSD loading times, and the fundamental uplift that the console provided.

Spider-Man 2’s PC port actually scaled back down to GPUs without ray-tracing features, with a broad set of hardware and performance targets to go from 720p30 up to full 4K with “Ultimate” ray tracing.

The problems that players are encountering seem to run the full gamut, and affect both Nvidia and AMD GPUs alike with performance dips, frame rate stutters and running out of VRAM even with a 16GB card. The majority of PC gamers have gone with Nvidia, and with many newly implemented graphical options seem to come plenty of problems.

Odd driver issues can lead to full-blown crashes citing GPU temperatures. Elsewhere Nvidia’s bespoke ray reconstruction for improving ray traced reflections and certain other DLSS features are claimed to actually reduce frame rates.

One user has a potential performance aid, saying “Before you play, open the install folder of the game,make a new folder and drag dsstorage.dll and dsstoragecore.dll into the new folder to improve load times, low fps and micro freezes!”

Essentially, this ditches the game’s use of Direct Storage, which has certain requirements for SSD speeds and technology. It’s not clear how this would help, as in theory it would reduce SSD read performance, but perhaps there are some bugs with the system.

As for the other issues, turning down ray-tracing effects and relying less on DLSS features that use AI to fill in the blanks seems to have an effect. In general, it feels like players will want to wait for a patch from Nixxes and a fresh driver update from Nvidia and AMD. Nvidia is also juggling a new GPU generation launch and adding more trickery to their drivers right around now.
